content:
years the lass="word-wrap-span">appointment of a new team at the lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">Commission is a chance to steer the lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">Union (

) in a fresh direction. On lass="word-wrap-span">September 10th lass="word-wrap-span">Ursula von der Leyen, the incoming boss, set out her priorities: managing the transition from lass="word-wrap-span">fossil fuels, extra lass="word-wrap-span">dollops of lass="word-wrap-span">American big-tech bashing and “upgrading our unique social market economy”.

lass="word-wrap-span">The first two at least have lass="word-wrap-span">The benefit of being clear. On lass="word-wrap-span">The economy, however, lass="word-wrap-span">Europe needs a lot more than blalass="word-wrap-span">Ther. In lass="word-wrap-span">The past decade lass="word-wrap-span">The trend of economic lass="word-wrap-span">integration that defined post-war lass="word-wrap-span">Europe has gone lass="word-wrap-span">backwards. lass="word-wrap-span">The “single market”, once breathtaking in its ambition to lass="word-wrap-span">eliminate all internal

barriers for lass="word-wrap-span">goods, services, capital and people, has lass="word-wrap-span">failed to keep up with the economies it was trying to shape. If lass="word-wrap-span">Europe wants to create prosperity and world-beating firms, it needs not just to reinvigorate the single market, but also to rediscover that original vision in neglected areas of trade such as services.

lass="word-wrap-span">The single market still matters—look at lass="word-wrap-span">The mess lass="word-wrap-span">Britain finds itself in as it tries to lass="word-wrap-span">extricate itself from lass="word-wrap-span">The

. lass="word-wrap-span">But a policy originally devised to break down trade barriers in the era of coal and steel has not adapted fast enough to the era of bits and likes (see lass="word-wrap-span">Briefing ). In the past decade lass="word-wrap-span">Europe’s lass="word-wrap-span">banks have retrenched to their home markets and its firms have shifted their energies to expanding outside the

. As a result, lass="word-wrap-span">Europe still looks like a series of mid-sized economies patched together, not a single rival to lass="word-wrap-span">China and lass="word-wrap-span">America.

lass="word-wrap-span">That is one reason why, even as central lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">bankers lass="word-wrap-span">administer a lass="word-wrap-span">drip-feed of monetary lass="word-wrap-span">adrenalin, lass="word-wrap-span">Europe’s economy is losing ground to global rivals. It risks becoming a business lass="word-wrap-span">backwater. A decade ago ten of the world’s 40 largest listed firms by market value were based in the

; now only two are—in 32nd and 36th place. lass="word-wrap-span">Desperately few of the world’s leading startups are lass="word-wrap-span">European.

lass="word-wrap-span">Policymakers who lass="word-wrap-span">ache at lass="word-wrap-span">The absence of a lass="word-wrap-span">European tech success on lass="word-wrap-span">The scale of Google or lass="word-wrap-span">Amazon pay lip service to lass="word-wrap-span">The importance of lass="word-wrap-span">The single market. lass="word-wrap-span">And yet lass="word-wrap-span">France lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Germany argue that lass="word-wrap-span">The real answer is dirigiste industrial policy. lass="word-wrap-span">They have called for mergers of lass="word-wrap-span">European firms to create industrial “champions” shielded from lass="word-wrap-span">antitrust rules lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese competition.

lass="word-wrap-span">They should be aiming to complete lass="word-wrap-span">The single market instead. A lass="word-wrap-span">functional single market helps firms achieve economies of scale. It is cheaper to make a product that has to meet one set of

regulations than to try to follow 28 different national rulebooks. lass="word-wrap-span">Stiffer competition from firms across the lass="word-wrap-span">continent means that shoppers get better and cheaper stuff. lass="word-wrap-span">Imagine if the dozens of mobile operators in lass="word-wrap-span">Europe were free to pitch their data plans to those beyond their national borders. lass="word-wrap-span">Instead, consumers have to make do with higher-charging local oligopolies.

lass="word-wrap-span">Innovation spreads faster in a unified market, pepping up productivity. A properly lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">integrated energy lass="word-wrap-span">grid would boost the most efficient (and lass="word-wrap-span">greenest) power producers. lass="word-wrap-span">Banks with loans out across the lass="word-wrap-span">continent avoid trouble if their home market falls into recession. lass="word-wrap-span">Capital markets on a lass="word-wrap-span">continental scale can help them lass="word-wrap-span">distribute risks beyond the lass="word-wrap-span">Banking sector. lass="word-wrap-span">Safer lass="word-wrap-span">Banks and deeper markets mean cheaper lass="word-wrap-span">Capital and fewer lass="word-wrap-span">bail-outs.

lass="word-wrap-span">For all those reasons, reinvigorating lass="word-wrap-span">The single market ought to be at lass="word-wrap-span">The centre of lass="word-wrap-span">The debate on how to boost lass="word-wrap-span">Europe’s economy. It is not. lass="word-wrap-span">Since her lass="word-wrap-span">appointment two months ago Mrs von der Leyen has mentioned lass="word-wrap-span">The single market only in passing (see article ). lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">commissioner in charge of lass="word-wrap-span">The brief, lass="word-wrap-span">Sylvie Goulard of lass="word-wrap-span">France, is well regarded, but will have to split her time between internal-market duties, regulating lass="word-wrap-span">artificial intelligence, and a new defence-industry and space brief.

lass="word-wrap-span">That might be understandable if lass="word-wrap-span">The single market were beyond saving. In fact it can be revitalised in three ways. lass="word-wrap-span">The first is to ensure lass="word-wrap-span">That its statutes are fully lass="word-wrap-span">implemented. lass="word-wrap-span">Too often, national governments lass="word-wrap-span">flout lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">edicts of lass="word-wrap-span">The single market so as to protect a politically connected industry. On average, each lass="word-wrap-span">European country regulates lass="word-wrap-span">The workings of nearly 200 professions, making it needlessly tricky for lass="word-wrap-span">Europeans to move to where lass="word-wrap-span">The jobs are. No wonder bits of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">continent still have double-digit unemployment. lass="word-wrap-span">The new lass="word-wrap-span">Brussels team should step up lass="word-wrap-span">enforcement against governments lass="word-wrap-span">That fail to apply lass="word-wrap-span">The rules.

lass="word-wrap-span">The second way is to focus on lass="word-wrap-span">The euro. lass="word-wrap-span">The single currency is in some ways an extension of lass="word-wrap-span">The single market, even if fewer countries belong to it. It would be more stable if a central fund lass="word-wrap-span">insured lass="word-wrap-span">bank lass="word-wrap-span">deposits. A more substantial euro-zone budget, focused on unemployment insurance, say, could help lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">integrate euro-zone economies. As an added benefit, this would also deepen cross-border links, notably by helping lass="word-wrap-span">banks become truly lass="word-wrap-span">European. lass="word-wrap-span">Here, Mrs von der Leyen has a harder task. lass="word-wrap-span">Her native lass="word-wrap-span">Germany will seek to keep progress lass="word-wrap-span">glacial.

lass="word-wrap-span">Most ambitious would be a fresh push to remove what structural barriers remain to cross-border lass="word-wrap-span">European trade. lass="word-wrap-span">Collecting value-added tax in a neighbouring country would not be so lass="word-wrap-span">daunting for small businesses if the levy was structured in the same way across lass="word-wrap-span">Europe, for example. lass="word-wrap-span">Banks would pitch their wares more broadly if lass="word-wrap-span">Bankruptcy laws were harmonised, and a proper capital-markets union created. lass="word-wrap-span">Standard lass="word-wrap-span">contracts for business services (on professional liability, say) would make it easier for lass="word-wrap-span">German accountants to tout for business in lass="word-wrap-span">Italy, or for Spanish architects to pitch their offerings beyond the lass="word-wrap-span">Pyrenees.

A grand bargain of policies serving up tax reform, services liberalisation and a more robust euro would run into plenty of national red lines. lass="word-wrap-span">But each country would also have lots to gain. lass="word-wrap-span">Europe needs to shield itself from the lass="word-wrap-span">fallout a global trade war might bring. It needs a vision after the lass="word-wrap-span">departure of lass="word-wrap-span">Britain, the single market’s most reliable champion in lass="word-wrap-span">Brussels—lass="word-wrap-span">But also, often, a brake on ambitious projects. lass="word-wrap-span">Meanwhile, Britons tempted to say lass="word-wrap-span">good riddance to the single market’s lass="word-wrap-span">frustrations should reflect on how much losing a seat at the table could cost them.

lass="word-wrap-span">Jacques Delors, a former head of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">Commission who championed closer lass="word-wrap-span">integration, rightly pointed out that “nobody can fall in love with lass="word-wrap-span">The single market”. lass="word-wrap-span">There is nothing lass="word-wrap-span">flashy about reworking lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">bankruptcy rules or tax regimes. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">Europe’s lass="word-wrap-span">greatest economic project is half-finished business, yielding just half lass="word-wrap-span">The benefits it could. lass="word-wrap-span">Europe has few such obvious levers to pull to boost its economy. lass="word-wrap-span">Time to tug on this one.
